thread.title: Telstra not really a phone company anymore
thread.title_full: Telstra not really a phone company anymore | afr.com

author: John McDuling
title: Telstra not really a phone company anymore
text:
Remember those? Virginia Star But aside from all that, its result reveals something quite profound.
Telstra's original business of landline phones is now a smaller part of its overall finances than ever before.
The company generated just $3.75 billion in revenue from fixed-voice services, less than 15 per cent of its total revenue of $26.6 billion.
Its internet products, data & IP, cloud computing and fixed broadband offerings make much more money than its legacy landline phone business.
Related Quote: s 5 years 1 Day Last updated: Updating... Last updated: Updating... View full Quote: Company Profile ASX Announcements Expand ASX Announcements View all announcements Telstra half-year revenue Sure, the biggest chunk of Telstra's revenue comes from mobiles ($10.7 billion).
But the mobile business is increasingly about data - providing access to the internet, on phones, tablets and an increasing array of devices - rather than about making calls on phones.
Telstra's former CEO, David Thodey, used to say his dream for Telstra was to become a truly great technology company, and that remains the mantra of new boss Andy Penn.
It's not there yet. But it's certainly not just a phone company anymore.
